description.text: For displaying or holding an object. Simple and easy to print. Change size accordingly to your requirements.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/1Wvle2tb5iM
Create a bracelet and add some text. Visit http://3km.ch/openjscad/

Instead of printing the whole model, you just do a part of the shell. In your slicer change the settings of:
  • Bottom and top thickness to: 0 [mm] It does not print a bottom and a cap.
  • Infill or Fill density: 0 [%] You want it hollow, don't you?
  • Shell thickness: 0.4 [mm] It depends on your nozzle size (mine is 0.4).
    • See also:
  • http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13505/#instructions
  • http://blog.prdcz.com/3D/2014/07/22/stream-print/
    • That's it! Have fun and tell me, if it worked. :)

description.text:
A part fan mount for a RigidBot single extruder (might work on a double). I like it because it keeps the fan out of the way.
The bracket leaves just enough room to hit the tension lever with a screwdriver and it screws down using the two screws for the bearing.
It's designed to be used with this fan: http://amzn.com/B00H8VV0XK
but others may work.
The duct works well and doesn't blow on the hot end enough to matter. It snaps into place but I don't trust it so I used tape just to be sure.
Finally, the fan mount poles have a hole in them near the end for a pin or a bar to hold the fan on. I used a rubber band and it works fine. Update 10/2016: Fixed the scaling issues. Should work without any scaling now.

Printed in PLA at 80 mm/s .2mm layer height.
The mount should print fine as-is but the duct does well with support touching buildplate in Cura. Works with Simplify 3d.

description.text:
For attaching strap to awning on a motorhome (aka RV).
The store bought awning pulls are stitched right into the plastic rod which is great right up until the strap dry rots which it envariable does right where it attaches. It is a real bear to try to stich into the plastic by hand if you need to repair one.
My anchor has a slot so that you can cut off the end, rethread it and restitch it and you are back in business. If I haven't explained this very well, this link to a store bought version might enlighten you:
http://www.amazon.com/Systems-940001-94-5-Awning-Strap/dp/B0002I94CK/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1410818118&sr=8-2&keywords=awning+pull
This is the magen david for year 5775 - Shanah Tovah

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NyYP5UVp-x0&feature=youtu.be
Probably of little use to anybody else but perhaps it may be,please let me know if you use them, for anything.
These are small bungs that I use to bung up the jets in my home spa jacuzzi thing in order to squirt water through just one at a time to clear them out. If I know I wont be using it for a few days I don't like the idea of my last baths water hanging around inside the tubes. Likewise if I haven't done this before not using it I most certainly do it before using it next time.
I use water pressure to feed the water in using the input adapter, I didnt bother with a thread it didnt need it.
These are 16mm, scale accordingly, they have an extra edge to ensure you can extract them even if they have a tight fit. They are designed to be quick and cheap in terms of plastic,not to be stylish or classy :)

I printed in PLA,5% infill, with 2 shells.
The 160is because it is 16.0mm diameter.
The x4 version is just 4 on the build plate.

title: Mendel Mounting cradle for Ramps1.4 plus Arduino

description.text: This is my solution for mounting an Arduino Mega2560 with a Ramps 1.4, inside a mount cradle - to an Alloy Mendel,or others with alloy extrusion with 8mm slots.

This is my mounting solution for use on Alloy Mendel by dkennell thing16076,for  an Arduino Mega2560 and Ramps1.4 - to be used with 30x30mm Alloy extrusion,it will require one of my other things " big foot " to allow enough clearance height, it has two 8mm strips on its sides to help align it with slots in alloy extrusion,with 4 x 5mm mount holes -  will require the 4 holes in the base tapping m3, and it has a rebate in top edge to allow fitting of a perspex lid in which you can drill mount holes/slots for mounting a 40x40mm 12v fan above the stepper motor boards for cooling.

title: X-Wing Miniatures XX-9 Death Star Turret

description.text: A Death Star Turret for Star Wars X-Wing, with snap on rotating turret top and a destroyed version that fits below it.

Hi all, got this idea from some of the death star turrets on eBay made of paper. This one isn't particularly patterned on a model, so I apologize for the inaccuracy. I've used the instructions here for most of the games I've played so far: http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/1021710/turret-ruleset-death-star-turbolaser All you have to do is glue the gun section together, then glue the turret top together. Everything else is intended as a press fit. Feel free to paint it however you like!

comments.text:
For anybody slicing the files in CURA:
I had to scale several parts differently. The files must use different units for different files (or at least CURA thinks so). Some parts were super tiny and some parts were super humongous. Note: 25.4 mm = 1 inch. The barrels and the mounts appear to be saved using inches, but CURA treats them as mm so you have to multiply by 25.4 to scale right. The Turret Barrel Backs however were off by not only the x25.4 but then 100 times to large also. It took some experimenting, but I think that's correct. For the Barrel Backs you have to multiply by a scaler of 0.0254 (which is multiplying by 25.4 to get inches and then dividing by 100). The base, top, and blown up version of the base were all correct with a scale multiplier of 1.0, so they must have been converted to mm before the files were saved or something. Summary list of scale multipliers by part is below.

comments.text: I don't think that copying this design is philosophically a problem for the community.  This site was created by and frequented by those who create and fix.  The way I see it (and I am not a lawyer) is that this is akin to reproducing a replacement part.  There are many, many examples on this site of commercially made and designed parts that have been reproduced.  Often this is done to fix or augment the functionality of something that would be otherwise be discarded when a small part of it inevitably breaks.  One could argue that he is creating a copy of this "vintage" toy so that he can he or others can play with it without the worry of breaking the original.  More likely, he recreated it to demonstrate his cad abilities and the capabilities of his commercial 3D printers.  His license also indicates that it is for non-commercial use only. I don't think the debate should be about whether he blatantly copied a commercial product and how it may be detrimental to the OS 3D community but, what are the rules for copyright and trademark that I might inadvertently run afoul of.  I have listened to Adrian Bower's talks about where the laws stand in Europe, but unfortunately I still don't know how it differs from American law.  If there is a good resource for learning about copyrights and trademarks and how it deals with our community (especially in America) I would be very appreciative.

My point is there are LOTS of designs on here that have been "reproduced" from company's products.  Are some of them violating laws?  Probably without a doubt!  This design and others of mine are not violating any laws to the best of my knowledge.

Tamper and Ring set to make the preparation of a 6 cup Moka pot a bit less messy. The ring helps the coffee grounds to stay in place inside the coffee container of the Moka and also prevents them from getting on the top surface of the container so that they aren't caught in the gasket.
NOTE: I accidentally deleted the previous upload. This is the same Thing as before.

• Printed on a Replicator Dual (uses 2 colors)
  • Layer height: 0.2 mm
  • Enable supports

    Print the tamper on its own.

    NOTE: Printing the bottom of the top sphere of the tamper can be tricky. It doesn't require supports, but if the ABS doesn't cool off quickly enough, the layers won't stick and it will come out looking badly. I fixed this by slowing down the prints as much as I could around that area. Blowing on the part actually helps, too!

    Print the ring and the ring stripe together, one in each color.

    The stripe is level with the top of the coffee container/holder, so it serves as an indicator of when you've added enough coffee grounds. If you have a single extruder, print both parts, otherwise the void left by the ring will allow the coffee grounds to get on top of the coffee container.

    Print the base and the coffee bean together in different colors.

    Make sure that the coffee bean is at the correct height from the platform so the surfaces of the bean and the base are flush. Also make sure that the bean is oriented correctly so the bend in the middle matches. If you have a single extruder, printing the base without the coffee bean probably looks better than printing the bean in the same color.

title: Mendel Power supply mount system for Alloy Mendel

description.text: This is my solution to mount a 12v 16A power supply to an Alloy Mendel between Y axis rods.

This is my solution to mount a 12v 16A power supply, enough amps to power ramps and 11w prussa pcb heatbed ( 200mmx110mmx40mm approx ) purchased via ebay from China.For fittment to dkennell thing 16076 - it comprises four different. Stl files, side hangers x2,cradle x 1, power input x 1,lid x1. And a 300mm and 175mm lengths of m6 allthread,and nuts and washers. It allows the fittment of a fused switched iec 3 pin socket at rear, and covers safeley the wiring connections to the power supply, and allows wiring out to ramps. It allows fittment of the power supply between the Y axis rods,and requires one of my other things, big foot -to give enough clearance from base.works in conjunction with my Ramps holder

Object was made during the 2nd intro to 3d printing class taught by Chris Ready and Jeffrey Wood of Makesalot has no title attribute. guest teaching at the Austin Tinkering School Austin Tinkering School.
This is a partial relief map of the surface of the moon as extrapolated from data from the Clementine spacecraftx

Using height data available from various sources I generated a relief map of the dark side of the Moon, then sliced it into 66 sections, each about 128,000 square km. Then I turned those gray-scale height maps into 3D plates using the excellent HeightmapToSTL tool.
So far I've only printed 9 of the tiles. They look really good when placed edge to edge, but I want to redo the height map with more detail and make 256 tiles with much higher contrast and donate it all as an installation to the Challenger Learning Center.
The problem would be the amount of time it takes to print each plate...:-)

This is a system for using a Nikon camera with a lens reversing ring to scan 110 film.  The reversing ring allows for a short focal length and high magnification perfect for negative scanning.

In addition to your printed pieces, you will need...
Nikon SLR and F mount lens
Nikon lens reversing ring (I use the BR-2A)
Light source (tablet or cell phone screen works well using a flashlight application)
ML-L3 IR remote or a programmable universal remote are useful for triggering the camera Prior to printing the tube, you will need to determine the desired tube length. Put on the lens reversing ring and your reversed lens. By adjusting the focus (and zoom if you have it), determine the appropriate distance from a negative to produce a mostly full frame image of the negative. This is your tube length. Put the tube length into the customizer and generate your custom STL. If you have a 50mm lens, the included STL should work. As you can see by the photo of my setup, black plastic doesn't appear to be required for good results. The table looking object is used to raise the focal plane away from the light source. This, or some frosted glass is needed if you are using something like an iPad. If not used, you will see the individual pixels shining through the image. With the reversing ring, the focal length is relatively short so this small table is sufficient to blur the individual pixels into a nice even white light source. As illustrated in the photo, the light source goes on the bottom (if you use an iPad, just put the table on the face of the iPad). Run a flashlight application on the light source. The film goes on the table with the image you wish to photograph over the hole. Look through your camera with the lens reversing ring and tube attached (focus and zoom as needed). You will need to have your camera in manual mode since the reversing ring breaks the cameras contact with the lens electronics. Be sure the physical aperture on the lens is wide open to minimize exposure time and keep the focal plane narrow. A remote trigger helps as you will find you need about a 1/2 to 1/20 second photo to appropriately expose the shot. Touching the camera during the shot could blur the image. Check your histograms so you use as much of the exposure range as possible. This will give you the most room for adjustment later. Once you have the photos taken, move them to your computer and open them in your editing program of choice. Crop, invert, and level balance it and you should get a great image. I plan to work out a similar system for 35mm film, but 110 was my first try since I have lots of shots from my childhood. 35mm will require flaring of the tube and bigger holes on the tube and table. This is still a work in progress, but it does work just fine. I'll update the design as I use it. Note the cat picture is an example scan. The photo was taken in 1986 using a 110 film camera.

remixed_from.author: dacb
remixed_from.title: Rounded plate with two holes (parametric); Adjustable offset for print cooling systems

title: Rounded plate with rotatable mount (parametric); Adjustable mount for print cooling systems

description.text:
This is a mounting plate for a rotatable object, e.g. a print cooling fan duct. It is parameterized by two mounting holes of a specified distance center-to-center and diameter in a plate with rounded edges. From this plate extends a specified number of attachment points characterized by their length and width in addition to the diameter of a hole that can be used for mounting something else, e.g. a print cooling duct or offsets or ... The number of interleaves is variable as is the spacing between them. Combine with: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:463758 To mount devices such as:
  • http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:462768
  • http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:431506
  • http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:351280
  • http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:225126
  • http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:73714
  • http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:31213
  • http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:30721
  • and on and on...

• Open the .jscad file at http://openjscad.org
  • In the editor, adjust the parametric variables (e.g. plate thickness, # of attachments, interleave spacing, etc.)
  • Render STL
  • Render GCODE
  • PRINT!

title: OnePlus One Holder for my Car Mount

description.text:
This is a holder that perfectly fits my OnePlus One WITH CASE COVER! The only holders available online are fitted for OPO without a case which is kinda stupid. And I didn't want to use any of the universal holders, as they are too fiddly...
So I drew my own holder that fits the feet of my car mount. They are arranged in a 23mm x 36mm rectangular, so if your car mount has different feet, it won't work.
I printed it with 1mm wall, 20% infill and 0.6 Bottom/Top thickness...

OPO_Holder2 is a Holder wide enough to fit an OPO's with a protection case.
OPO Holder No Case fits an OPO without any case. I printed it both in ABS and PLA with 50% infill.

comments.text:
Too tight for my OPO without cover (and I calibrated my printer recently)
Scratched the sides of my sandstone backcover to hell when trying to get it in/back out. So beware!
Sadly I didn't look closely enough before printing, I thought that the sides would taper to the front in some kind of clip-style, but they are just straight.

remixed_from.title: iPhone 5 Gear Case with Geneva Mechanism

remixed_from.author: QuentinT
remixed_from.title: Improved! iPhone Gear Case with Geneva Mechanism

title: (thinner) iPhone 5 gear case with Geneva mechanism

description.text: This is a remix of the awesome iPhone 5 gear case by Brandonw6, which in turn was derived from the awesome iPhone 4 gear case by QuentinT. I've redesigned the case to make it thinner and eliminate the seam along the side. It is now 2mm thinner all the way around, and 5mm shorter. And no seam :) If you had previously downloaded or printed this case, you might want to re-download and check out the changes. The pins were widened a bit so they fit properly, and the 35-tooth Geneva driver gear was modified to mesh properly with the Geneva wheel. This was tested with PLA on a MakerBot2 and worked great at standard settings (see picture). Please see instructions for printing and assembly comments.

Print the case back and the case frame horizontally with rafts; I put "ears" at the ends to eliminate warping. You can print all the gears and all the pins at once, also with a raft. (Depending on what color combination you want, you might do multiple prints!) The case back fits tightly inside the frame; you might have to sand lightly for a perfect fit. Press the case back all the way up against the little stops at the bottom of the frame. Make sure the flat side of the case back faces the "inside" of the case, where the phone will be, and that the camera hole in the case back is just below the notch for power button. After the back fits snugly, superglue all the way around the seam between the back and the frame on the back side, where the phone will be. After this dries you can test the fit with a phone. Next fasten all the gears to the eback by pressing their pins through the gears and into the back. You might have to scrape out the holes in the gears a little with a knife. The pins should be pretty tight; usage will loosen them up. After all the gears are inserted, test the gear meshing by lightly turning with the gear chuck. Make sure the pins are pressed all the way into the case back. When all is well, put a drop of superglue on the back of each pin. That's it; insert your phone, and enjoy! *I've uploaded Makerbot thing files with ears for the case back, case frame, all gears, and all pins.

remixed_from.title: Z-Axis Double Rod Stabilizer for Printrbot

description.text:
Printrbot Stabilizer mounted at the top of the Z -axis. Not sure if it reduces Z wobble but may provide more frame rigidity. I have no issues with Z wobble but if you're playing around with acceleration, doesn't hurt to add this.  
Provided both 8mm and 12mm mount for the Printrbot and Printrbot Plus.  
Can be clamped on and off for easier installation and the horizontal rod can be installed without threading through the parts.

• Print two
    • Hardware needed: SI
    QTY
    2 M3 x 14mm
    2 M3 nuts
    1 M8 x 400mm (plus), non plus (??)
    4 M8 washers
    4 M8 nuts SAE
    2 #6-32 x 1/2" (#5-40 or #4-40 may be a better choice)
    2 #6-32 nuts
    1 5/16" x 16" (plus), non plus (??)
    4 1/4" washers (inner diameter is about 5/16", they will fit)
    4 5/16" nuts .IGES file included

comments.text: Only problem with this is that it reduces your available Z-height as the E-motor runs into the stabiliser. Less of an issue on the PB+, but a showstopper for me on an original PB. Good idea though so I make try to make a derivative that's less obstructionist to the Z travel.

author: dendrobates

description.text:
Just doing my part to make the tools needed to build a MakerBot printable.
The wrench is a 1cm metric-- you can use a pair of calipers and Blender to drag the jaws of the model to any size you like, though!  The wrench has been rotated exactly 45 degrees so it'll fit in the build area-- you'd be well served to reverse that operation before dragging verts around.
The hex key is 2mm thick-- you should be able to scale it to any size you need, although you may have to shorten the handle to make it fit in the build area at larger diameters...

title: Silent extruder gears (Rapman)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The standard acrylic involute gears were driving me nuts with their incessant CLICK-CLACK CLICK-CLACK noises, so I designed these herringbone gears to replace them. Now I can't hear my printer from the next room :)
The motor gear has a 'floor' to help you position the grub/nut easily and precisely. The rebate for the nut has also been set back from the shaft a bit to make it easier to fit than ever.
An additional advantage is that they are constantly in mesh, so there is no slack to take up when reversing direction (if you use M227, this happens hundreds/thousands of times each print!) so you will have cleaner prints too.

Print using your favourite settings (no support material required) however do NOT print with PLA as the extruder motor heat will soften the drive gear and the grub nut will come loose.
When installing, replace the split-ring washer on the extruder drive shaft with a new M8 flat washer, and place the split-ring between the original washer and nut. This keeps everything from coming loose without letting the split-ring tilt the driven gear.
Lastly, face the grub slot up for aesthetics - not only will it hide the slot, but from the front of the machine the driven gear will look like arrows pointing and moving towards the filament.

A friend needed a suspended mount for his microphone but since I didn't really liked the existing designs I made my own.  :)  
The idea is really simple. The mike is held in the middle using cross-mounted rubber bands. The knob is mounted on the mike stand. The inside diameter of the cylinder is 100mm.  
The printed version shown in the pictures is an earlier variant but the basic dimensions is the same. I've printed it with both 20% and 40% infill and both feels sturdy and reliable.

comments.author: random11

comments.text:
to "Acetone Hot vapor polish" I use this method:
get a asparagus cooking pot (tall narrow pot with a basket to hold the asparagus)
I put a disc of aluminum foil (thick stuff from a take-out tin) on the bottom of the basket.
put model on the disc, in the basket.
2-3 tablespoons of acetone in the pot. heat on a electric hotplate.
put basket in pot with lid on tight 30 - 40 seconds
remove basket, air dry for 1-2 minutes.
a glass lid is a big plus, you can watch the model as it wets from bottom to top,
remove when top is wet.(usually 30-40 seconds)

"A zinc finger is a small protein structural motif that is characterized by the coordination of one or more zinc ions in order to stabilize the fold."
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zinc_finger
Zinc fingers bind DNA and act as transcription factors. This zinc finger binds a zinc ion through two cysteine and two histidine residues. This zinc finger model is based on PDB model 3IUF:
http://www.rcsb.org/pdb/explore/explore.do?structureId=3iuf
Model created using VMD:

author: gavinpotter

title: A Better Dewalt 621 Router Depth Stop

description.text:
The Dewalt 621 Router is a great tool, but it comes with this poorly designed stop that uses screws with locking nuts.  This part replaces the OEM stop with wide fixed steps of 1/8" allowing you to set your depth and then quickly take multiple passes easily for deeper cuts.   
Let me know if you print one or find it useful. I think it's a great upgrade to a good tool.  My Larger Bosch router has one that inspired this upgrade.  I shared a drawing of the part so you can  make one with different stop depths if you so desire.

Ivy Pendent.
1" wide by 2" long pendent flower pot, with living ivy growing out of it.
Ivy is not printed but planted into the printed pot.
The pendent it self is interchangeable creating the ability to mix and match different potted plants with ones mood, or wardrobe. This is part of a series of costume and jewellery accessories I am making.
The series combines Organic matter and Technology to create simple and provocative jewellery and adornments for ones clothing, and ones self. The project is meant so that no matter where one goes, an individual may carry with them a little piece of nature with them. Plants have known to effect mood especially in city's where green spaces benefit an individuals health, and can aid in relieving stress. Not everyone in there day can get to a green space due to many contributing factors, but with a few minutes a day one can grow and express their own personal green space.

Print the pot. Use the holes on the sides to sting threw what you wish to hand the pendent from.
Take potting soil and fill the interior space of the pot, and add seedling, wild flower, or Ivy.
Wear the pendent, or hang it from the wall. For a more complex pendent a basic jewellery making kit may be required.
Containing the following;
-Snub nose pliers
-Round nose pliers
-Wire cutters
  • 1 length of wire rope
  • 6 finishing cap beads
  • 1 jump ring
  • 5 locking beads (ones squeezed onto the wire)
    • Steps; 1) feed the jump ring on.
    2) feed 1 locking bead so that both cut ends feed threw it. This will lock the jump ring in place.
    3) feed 1 lock bead on either side of the jump ring
    4) feed the wire rope threw either side of the pot forming a U
    5) on both ends of the wire rope lock the beads as close to the end as possible.
    6) take the 2 lock beads close to the jump ring and place them at the top of the pot as close as possible to create a snug fit. Lock these beads in place.
    7) hold the jump ring so it takes the wait of the pendent. Do this to find the centre of the wire rope and lock it in place with the remaining lock bead.
    8) All beads should be locked in place now. Over each one place a finishing bead.
    9) the remaining finishing bead is to go on the jump ring and wire rope union.
    ensure the union has the jump rings own union included. secure finishing bead over the union.

author: transilvio

title: Amsterdamman's Stabilized Z axis Herringbone Gear for Reprap Ormerod

description.text:
Edit Both gears slightly changed - Drive Gear: I found a small off-center in the position of the drive gear hole. This corrects that error. The Stabilized Gear: I removed the flare around the inner hex nut hole which makes it slightly tighter on the top giving the bearing a better surface to sit on. Stabilized Z-axis herringbone gear with nuts on both sides of the gear.
I was unsatisfied with the performance of my Z axis and the lack of centered rotation I saw on the threaded Z axis rod. I printed some herringbone gears but they didn't fit my machine - maybe it was the fault of my printer, I just started last month. I pulled apart the gears in Sketchup and started to rebuild parts. Eventually I ended up rebuilding the entire profile of the gear using the dimensions of the original but reworking the rest of the gear. Many iterations later I had a nice set of working and lash free herringbone gears on my Z axis and 98% of my Z issues have been solved between the gears, the extended Z axis nut holder and a set of Aluminum X-axis arms from Dave in the UK.
But the threaded rod was still not rotating centered due to the slight angle the gear takes when put against the threaded rod nut and the bearing top. My biggest improvement was to flip the nut cavity from the top to the bottom just over the bearing. This allows the second nut to squeeze the entire gear from above and centers it on the threaded rod. I printed a M5 washer as well since I didn't have one here, but did have a 3D printer!!

comments.text: I made two changes to the gears. The drive gear was corrected for a slightly off center hole. The stabilized gear now has a tighter top for the  inner hex nut giving the bearing a better surface to sit on.

https://reprappro.com/shop/reprap-kits/ormerod-2-kit/ Mine is a Ormerod 1, but I ordered a new Ormerod 2 which I will print the parts for :) Great machine and service with Sally and Ian - even if they can be overworked at times...

It is printed in red PLA with a mendel reprap. The slices are 0.2 mm to gain the details needed for printing in original size.
For that I just resized it to the size of standard lego (exactly factor 0.5). Because of the miniaturisation I had to change the hole for the clamp of the hips. Also I slightly increased the size of the arms for a better fit to the hands.
I glued some nails into the arms and put them into the holes of the torso. Now you can also move the arms!
For a better fit to lego bricks I cut of two squares into the legs - now it can stand on lego :-)
Print, assemble - and have fun!

You can print these simple toys using the .stl files or modify the design using Autodesk 123D design. These files come from my book, A Beginner's Guide to 3D Printing: 14 Simple Toy Designs to Get You Started (Chicago Review Press). How does a person with little or no computer design experience create an object to print? I think hands-on experience (an apprentice method) works well. The book goes through each toy, step-by-step with screen captured photos (using Autodesk 123D) for assistance. Word descriptions of the same projects using Sketchup are also included. The book is available worldwide, wherever fine books are sold.
Generally, print at the lowest resolution with supports.

comments.text: Had a little trouble with the dolls house due to my 3D printer being very vulnerable to temperature differences. Haven't been able up till now to print out a straight wall. Either it curls in one corner when I use no raft or when raft is used, I am not able to remove it afterwards seemed glued to it.  With raft on it I seem to not be able to use the clips correctly.... I have had trouble with larger square designs from the beginning....
comments.author: heartphone

comments.text: Scale smaller might work . . . I print the walls standing upright, but that's using PLA on a Makerbot Replicator. If I try something with too much surface area on the build plate, I'm not sure how I would get it unstuck. If the walls look pretty good, but the clips don't work because of the raft adding thickness, then scale the clips a little larger and see if that works.
comments.author: heartphone

comments.text: Yes me too have experimented printing the walls standing upright, the flat wall goes alright, the window and doorwall develop too much supportive raft and even looked more ugly than printed lying down. But since 3D printing is a neverending story of trial and error and then suddenly: result, I can say today that I clicked the dolls house together, except for the roof walls which I am printing out now as I write this.
comments.author: mrigsby

comments.text: I did already 6 projects (designing and 3D printing) Also translated a few pages. I will still have to find a way to combine the designing with taking the screenshots. I did with project 5 (the submarine, which is already a bit more difficult),  but had to start all over again a few times. So I now decided to design all the projects first and print them out, before taking screenshots and translating the text.
comments.author: heartphone

comments.text: This sounds like a good approach. After you do a few projects, you will see that "extruding", "cutting holes" and other processes are actually the same procedure (just different sizes and locations for different toys); then it may be easier to know which steps are next and when to take a screenshot.
comments.author: heartphone

comments.text: Thanks, yes it may be better for me to take screenshots when I really do understand what am doing lol :) I tried to follow exactly the screenshots in your book, but I already discovered that I can't do that and have to put in my own way. Anyway it is a great learning school and am having fun!
comments.author: mrigsby

comments.text: I've ordered your book through the online webstore Bol.com in my country (Netherlands) and received it today. Am going to work through it and print those designs for my grandkids. It is my intention to eventually teach (one of) my grandkids the art of designing and 3D printing. Therefore I would like to translate your book in my native language (Dutch). Could I get your permission to do that? In first instance only for my grandkids but maybe (if my translation is good enough) it will sell in my country too. There are no books at this moment that I know of in my country so straightforward as yours. Anyway, since I own a 3D Printer I have been waiting for a book like yours to appear :). So I will have fun with it!
comments.author: heartphone

comments.text: Yes, you have my permission to translate the book for your grandkids. If the Dutch translation generates sales interest in your country, I'm sure we can work out permission arrangements that will be beneficial for you and me.
comments.author: heartphone

comments.text: Thank you. Will keep you posted on my progress...
comments.author: mrigsby

title: CreatorBlocks the free opensource Isometric board game

description.text:
link to animated Gif that shows how it works http://anthonydavila.deviantart.com/art/OpenSorce-Isometric-Tabletop-game-479381430
I have been working on this idea for over 4 years,but it was only recently that it was possible for me to get a 3d prototype; I'm not an engineer, so, it may have some flaws but the printed prototypes so far come out great this idea started out as a chess board. I wanted to improve on the existing game, improve may not be the right word chess is a game that's already perfect but I wanted to make it a bit more interesting, I wanted this game to be affected by the environment and so I got inspired by games like tactics ogre, Dofus, Legos and many others that's how CREATOR BLOCKS was born, CREATOR BLOCKS is not just a chessboard its not just role playing tabletop game its an open source tabletop game in which you can make your own game rules and since you will have the 3d files they are compatible with any miniature set out there No mater the size, the file contains square tiles, hex tiles and triangle tiles, I have to admit this project took longer than I expected
Only recently, I saw someone release a very similar board game to mine, which means patenting my design is no longer an option don't get me wrong the only reason I even thought of patenting this was to protect myself from law suits vaulters are all around us, and since I'm not willing to throw away all the time spent designing this, I rather give it away, I will still work on making add-ons on my free time but only if I see interest in this project from people,
If you have any issues with the files let me know and I will do what I can to fix it,
it was modeled in 3ds max and its relatively simple to assemble together almost like Legos.

author: mrswhitehoosac

title: Brackets for PAX KOMPLEMENT Pull Out Clothes Rail

description.text:
The IKEA PAX is a 32mm European cabinet system.  It has many accessories in the KOMPLEMENT family including this pull-out clothes rail.  It is designed to mount to the bottom of a shelf, but I wanted to mount it to the side of the cabinet.  These brackets adapt the mounting ears of the KOMPLEMENT rail to the 32mm shelf pins on the cabinet.
This was a huge CAD victory:  I mocked up the side of the cabinet and the ears of the rail and drew brackets to join them up.  The very first print (with some hole cleanup) mounted to the rail and the holes perfectly aligned to the cabinet.  No trial and error at all!
The front bracket is slightly crooked in the STL (relative to the axes) due to the way I flipped it onto its side for printing, but the part itself is square.

Mirror the back bracket if mounting to the right side of the cabinet.
Print one of each bracket (I used 40% infill for strength).  Clean up the holes and ensure the 5mm pin fits cleanly but snugly into one of the shelf pin holes.
Slide one ear at the front of the KOMPLEMENT rail into the slot in the front bracket and use one of the screws that came with the rail to secure the inside ear to the bracket.  Use another one of the screws to mount the back bracket.  Use left-over screws from other IKEA projects to secure the bracket to the PAX cabinet.  If you need to buy screws for this they are called Varianta screws (or just "Euro screws") and you can get them at most hardware stores.
The result seems to be sturdier than the rail itself.

This is a motorized door lock inspired by The Amazing Spider Man. It makes use of a rack and pinion which converts the rotary movement of a servo motor to linear movement. Once the rack is extended, it fits into the "rack holder" which is screwed into your door frame. This model requires the use of a standard sized 180 degree servo motor (40.8 × 20.1 × 38 mm). If anyone needs the model to be updated to fit a smaller or larger motor, please leave a comment and I will upload the new models. UPDATE: The motor holder has been updated and redesigned to increase the strength and fix some modelling issues. UPDATE 2: The chamfer on the Gear model has been removed. The object will now print without the use of supports or slight drooping. Some coverage by Makerbot themselves: http://stories.makerbot.com/post/95939577127/locking-a-door-like-spider-man

Firstly print out all parts in the orientation that it was imported:
The "Gear" can be at a low infill (~20-30%). (No Support)
The "Motor_Holder" needs to be printed at a high resolution and high infill (~70-100%).(Support)
The "Rack" should be printed at about 50% infill and lastly, (No Support)
The "Rack_Holder" should be printed at 100% (No Support) The rack holder needs to be screwed into your door frame. Make sure it is well aligned so the rack fits nicely when it is extended. The rack will slot into the Motor_Holder but you may be required to add a plate on the top of the rack to prevent it from falling out when mounted on a door. If youre using it on a table or desk, you will not need to add the plate. Mount the motor into the large area on the Motor_Holder. The screws should line up nicely however you may need to tap or drill out the holes because of printer inaccuracies. M3 screws need to be used. Use M3 screws or bolts to mount the entire holder onto your door or on whatever you choose to use the mechanism on. The gear can then be screwed onto the servo motor using the screws which were provided when you bought the motor.

comments.author: gentijo

comments.text:
I have used Inventor before, I really like that package and Autodesk has a friendly edu license. TinkerCad is a really good, super entry level, solid modeling tool. I really like how it does subtraction by grouping a "hole" part with a solid part vs the cut style subtraction feature of MS 3D modeler. Where tinker CAD falls short for me is not being able to take measurements from arbitrary points and any notion of making an assembly. I just found OnShape from another Thingiverse project, it looks really nice, a lot of parallels to an Inventor / Solidworks style package and claims to import parts from many other systems. If you are ok with shared projects, the system is free and it supports full assemblies and looks like you can create fairly complex systems. I haven't used it for anything besides watching a few tutorials so far.
Since you want to share you project I would suggest looking at OnShape and creating an assembly, then animate it. See here https://www.onshape.com/videos/lets-make-an-assembly

comments.text: It will be strong enough to keep an honest person out. It's no where near strong enough for the zombie apocalypse. Anode has the right idea. If this were tweaked with a metal bar getting the linear motion from the printed parts and then some metal brackets positioned in the overall assembly by the printed parts. Where do we source the metal parts though? and how to we do it so that the metal is widely available? I think coat hangers would be the best resource. This is thin enough that we could bend the wire with printed tools and to make it strong have many metal wires reinforcing each other. A bundle of 50 wires from coat hangers is going to make a very serious bolt in a door.

author: Juanjo28

description.text: This is mostly an explanation of how to quickly make a custom mounting bracket for a complicated part. If you want to mount this motor: http://www.sciplus.com/p/CAR-SEAT-312VDC-GEAR-MOTOR_49248, use these files. Examine the original motor and all the curved/odd shapes look challenging. I just pushed the motor into some clay (Sculpey). Next I scanned the clay model. At Tinkercad.com, I combined the scanned clay base with a designed flat piece (plate with four holes). Then, using the Tinkercad "hole" tool, I made a couple of holes in the scanned piece where I could secure tie wraps. In just a few minutes design time (and a few hours print time), I created a secure mount and can continue working on my project.

comments.text: At first glance this seems counterintuitive, but then thinking about the possibilities for mounting things this way, it dawns on me that this is actually pretty damn brilliant.  Kudos!

description.text:
This easy to assemble shelf uses brackets from Home Depot and metal conduit tubing. The part itself is reversible and can be underslung.
Parts list:
2 Home Depot angle brackets: 7.25 in. x 7.25 in. White Over Under Shelf Bracket EB-0051-8WT.. $2.29 each
1 10' length 1/2" EMT Conduit.. $2.34
4 1/2"-5/8" Screws and nuts, 8/32 or 10/32
White spray paint
I also included a label ring.
Enjoy!

Print two bracket supports. I like 40% fill for these.
Cut EMT to length with a tube cutter or hacksaw. 42" is a comfortable stretch that shouldn't need a center support. The screws are for registration. Rivets or some other fasteners could also be used.

A fun thing to have.  I have never seen one except in sketches.  You can tell your friends that they inspired it.  It is not a reflection of me.  Approximately 1.2 inches 3 cm OD.  It was a challenge to design due to needing a spherical helix.  If you rotate the screw ball on your screen by holding down an arrow key it looks real cool if it rotates about the center axis. Have fun.

The foot is for adhesion to the printer surface.  It is very thin and breaks off easily after printing.  If you want to clean it up in a lathe you may want to print the one with the pedestal.  When I did not use support material I had to print it slow to give it a lot of cooling time and to avoid the edges curling up.  It is hollow.
